(Hillary Clinton, did not pressure harder for human rights and democratic practices, true)

[ (Sheikh Ali Salman, told BBC that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government had to show its willingness to offer "concrete solutions", BBC)
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, is seen as a reformist in a court divided on how to respond to opposition demands, BBC)
(Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, has been in his post since 1971, BBC)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, insisted that now was the time for dialogue, BBC)
(dialogue and negotiations are necessary, she believed that dialogue and negotiations were necessary, BBC)
(al-Wefaq leader, acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties, BBC)
(Sheikh Salman, believed that the only way forward was to work with reformists within the Sunni Muslim royal family, including Crown Prince Salman, BBC)
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, has long been considered a proponent of accommodation with Bahrain's Shia majority, BBC)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, noted that hours before King Hamad brought in GCC troops to restore order and crush dissent on 14 March 2011, the crown prince and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan, BBC)
(Senator John Kerry, he is hopeful that he will do more than his predecessor Hillary Clinton, Sheikh Salman)
(US policy needs to be more clear and direct, Sheikh Salman said the US government needs to pressure harder for human rights and democratic practices, Sheikh Salman)
(UK's approach to the crisis in Bahrain, the al-Wefaq leader was more blunt about the UK's role, BBC)
(Prime Minister David Cameron, Sheikh Salman asked if the British government should continue to say it privately and not put public pressure, BBC)
(opposition societies, six opposition societies have agreed on a dialogue process with the government, BBC)
(Sheikh Salman, also reiterated al-Wefaq's position that it would continue to call for peaceful demonstrations, BBC)
(public gatherings and rallies are currently banned in Bahrain, Sheikh Salman called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture, BBC) ]

[ (Sheikh Ali Salman, said, The only way open to us to put pressure on the government)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, believed, dialogue and negotiations are necessary)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said, We welcome it, we are ready for it)
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, is considered a reformist in the court divided on how to respond to opposition demands, )
(Sheikh Ali Salman, acknowledged that many young protesters had lost faith in the main opposition parties, A lot of young people do not believe...)
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, has long been considered a proponent of accommodation with Bahrain's Shia majority, )
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said, We had an agreement with the crown prince)
(Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, and opposition had agreed a seven-point plan that would have moved Bahrain towards a constitutional monarchy, The seven principles were announced and then 12 hours later, GCC troops came in and severed the dialogue)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, asked about the appointment of Senator John Kerry as US secretary of state, We are told that Mr Kerry has more interest in Bahrain and so we hope he will achieve more)
(US Secretary of State, needs to be more clear and direct, The United States government needs to pressure harder for human rights and democratic practices)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said about the UK's approach to the crisis in Bahrain, If the UK government and [Prime Minister David] Cameron are serious about putting an end to violence and human rights abuses, then they have to speak out publically)
(UK Government, needs to put public pressure, It is not enough to say: 'We are privately urging reform.')
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said about the current ban on public gatherings and rallies in Bahrain, It is the only way open to us to put pressure on the government)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, called for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture, They were convicted of plotting to overthrow the government)
(Sheikh Ali Salman, said that these people have a lot of followers in the street, If they are not part of the dialogue than the dialogue will fail)
(Senator John Kerry, has more interest in Bahrain, We are told that Mr Kerry has more interest in Bahrain and so we hope he will achieve more) ]
